awd_titl_txt: Atomistic Simulations of Acoustic Activation of Surface Processes
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports computational research into the fundamental mechanisms of the energy transfer from strong acoustic waves to the atomic-scale surface features. Surface acoustic waves are elastic waves that propagate along the surfaces of solid materials. Their ability to transfer energy long distances with little losses are actively used in many practical applications, ranging from nondestructive evaluation of mechanical properties to micro-scale manipulation of fluid flow in microfluidics devices. The ability of surface acoustic waves to influence atomic-level surfaces processes, however, remains largely unexplored. The results of this research will facilitate the development of new applications in the areas of chemical catalysis, low temperature thin film growth, and mass spectrometry of heat sensitive molecules. At a more general level, the results of this study may open up an exciting range of opportunities for using the acoustic waves as an alternative source of energy for non-thermal activation of surface processes under conditions where the temperature increase must be avoided. The involvement of students into all aspects of high-performance parallel computing and close interaction with experimental and computational collaborators will create a fertile educational environment in the quickly expanding area of scientific computing.

The goal of revealing the mechanisms responsible for the acoustic activation of surface processes will be achieved through the development of advanced computational methodology for atomistic modeling of free nonlinear propagation and dissipation of strong surface and bulk acoustic waves, as well as their interaction with surface structures and adsorbates. The new computational methods will be applied for a systematic investigation of frequency up-conversion, nonlinear sharpening of the wave profiles, shock formation and the onset of rapid dissipation of acoustic waves, acoustic energy coupling to surfaces adsorbates, sub-surface crystal defects, and nanoscale heterogeneities. The conditions leading to the diffusion enhancement, desorption, or atomic-level structural rearrangements in the surface region of the substrate will be elucidated in the simulations and the domains of applicability of the acoustically-assisted surface processing will be established for several material systems of practical interest.

por.por_cntn:
The experimental observations of the enhancement of diffusion, desorption, and surface catalysis by strong acoustic waves point toward the possibility of utilization of the acoustic stimulus in a broad range of applications ranging from thin film growth on heat-sensitive substrates to non-thermal desorption of fragile molecules for mass-spectrometry analysis. The lack of reliable theoretical interpretation of the intriguing experimental results, however, is hampering progress in the integration of the acoustic methods into mainstream analytical or materials synthesis techniques.

In the NSF-sponsored research, Professor Zhigilei and his team at the University of Virginia are developing and applying advanced multiscale computational models suitable for detailed investigation of the laser-induced generation of strong acoustic pulses, the nonlinear evolution of the acoustic pulses and shock front formation, as well as the interaction of the nonlinear acoustic pulses with surface species. In particular, the results of large-scale atomistic modeling of surface acoustic waves have revealed a new mechanism of the energy dissipation at the shock front formed in the course of the propagation and nonlinear sharpening of the waves, as well as the generation of localized zones of plastic deformation at a substantial distance from the wave source. The latter phenomenon, involving the emission of dislocations along the path of the wave propagation, has potential practical implications for applications where precise real-time surface modification is required.

The computational investigation of the interaction of acoustic waves with surface adsorbates and overlayers predicts the possibility of a highly effective acoustic desorption of atomic clusters at a substrate temperature almost 20 times lower than that required for thermally-activated desorption.  Moreover, the acoustic pulses are found to be capable of causing acoustic exfoliation of graphene multilayers of various thicknesses from a catalytic metal substrate. An analytical model based on the consideration of resonant coupling of high-frequency harmonics of the nonlinear acoustic waves with the vibrational modes of the adsorbates is formulated for the description of both the acoustic desorption of atomic clusters and exfoliation of thin graphene multilayers. The computational predictions have practical implications for interpretation of the results of laser-induced acoustic desorption mass spectrometry experiments and provide ideas for the development of new approaches utilizing the acoustic energy in thin film growth, transfer of 2D materials, and regeneration of catalytic activity of metal surfaces.

The broader impacts of this program are in the practical implications of the physical insights revealed in this project for a range of applications of the acoustic waves for surface characterization, desorption, thin film growth, and non-thermal surface processing. On the educational side, the program has provided training and multidisciplinary research experience to graduate students involved in this project. The students received a number of university-level and international research awards, including a prestigious 2020 Dieter W. B?uerle Prize for Fundamentals and Applications of Laser-Matter-Interactions. All students supported by this grant were trained in parallel programming and used high-performance computing resources at the NSF-supported Extreme Science and Engineering Discovery Environment (XSEDE). One of the students served as a co-PI on an XSEDE Research Allocation.

In order to catalyze the research activities in the research area supported by this NSF award, the PI served as a Guest Editor for May 2019 Special Issue of MRS Bulletin on Acoustic Processes in Materials. The Special Issue was publicized in an MRS Webinar hosted by the PI.
